termShortDefinition: A list of things to be done or considered
termExtendedDefinition: Agendas usually appear in the context of a meeting, or other deliberative process.  They are an attempt to list all of the issues that are to be addressed in a specific meeting, and also to put them in some meaningful order. An agenda is usually created before the meeting and given to participants to help them prepare.      There is another sense of the term: An agenda can also be an underlying ideological plan that motivates some actions.

termShortDefinition: A man-made object
termExtendedDefinition: Artifacts are things created by human beings, which do not occur through natural processes.  Artifacts are usually physical objects, but they can often be intangible things as well.  For instance, errors, mistakes, and misinterpretations that are the result of some flawed process are said to be artifacts of that process.

termShortDefinition: Something that improves well-being or a positive impact on goals and objectives.
termExtendedDefinition: Benefits can be abstract, because it is difficult to quantify \"well-being\" in a way that is true all the time.  However, discussing benefits in the context of transportation planning is perhaps most useful when some measurable criteria can be associated with them.

termShortDefinition: The expression of something that is of interest to a person.
termExtendedDefinition: A concern is of interest to a person because it has personal importance, or some effect on their lives.  Concerns can be expressed in terms of values, goals, objectives and criteria.

termShortDefinition: A convener initiates a decision situation, and serves as its sponsor who has the authority to covene a decision situation, e.g., the TIP manager at PSRC.
termExtendedDefinition: A convener is a person who has authority to invite people to participate in the transportation improvement decision process, and to establish the timeframe for carrying out the decision process.  A convener is responsible for making sure that all who should participate are invited to participate, for suggesting an initial agenda that addresses all aspects of the transportation improvement decision situation, for reviewing input from others, and for approving the final version.

termShortDefinition: The resources that need to be spent in order to construct or operate some part of a project.
The specific measure or test which reflects the degree of attainment of particular objectives.
termExtendedDefinition: Criteria result directly from the fact that the levels of attainment of the objectives of urban transportaiton planning are measurable. The derivation of criteria should be relatively straightforward if the goal set is properly defined. Criteria include the quantitative tests which are applied to alternative physical system plans in order to determine the degree to which they meet the stated objectives, and to compare alternative systems so that the one which most closely meets these objectives may be selected.

termShortDefinition: The idealized state of affairs an objective is meant to bring about.
termExtendedDefinition: Goals derive from the shared values held by people, and they should lead to some specific objectives that can be completed in order to meet them.  Goals are likely to be very vague -- for instance, \"improved safety\" is an example of a goal most people value.  However, by themselves, goals cannot be measured, and so it is impossible to know when they have been attained.  This is why specific objectives (and, in turn, criteria) are necessary.

termShortDefinition: A number of people (or objects) that are assembled together, or have some unifying relationship.
termExtendedDefinition: The defining characteristic of a group is that its members all have something in common that they do not have in common with people who are outside of the group.  This can be a shared concern, interest, physical location, or any other difference.

termShortDefinition: The affects of some activity on people, an environment, a system, or a culture.
termExtendedDefinition: Includes both negative and positive impacts.  Some activities have direct and immediate impacts, while other activities combine to have a cumulative impact.

termShortDefinition: A moderator facilitates and chauffeurs the decision situation process.
termExtendedDefinition: A moderator works to see that the discussion progresses smoothly and is fair for all participants.  A moderator arbitrates and mediates in order to avoid violence, or the breakdown of discussion.  The moderator works to see that the agenda is addressed.

termShortDefinition: A physical area with distinctive qualities, or a group of people who live in physical proximity to each other.
A specific example of something that must be achieved in order to reach a goal.
termExtendedDefinition: Objectives always have some reference to the physical world.  An example of an objective would be a statement such as \"decreasing the commuting time between West Seattle and Downtown.\"  This objective could derive from a general goal of improving traffic flow, for instance.  Objectives are a necessary part of any plan to satisfy a goal.  Likewise, specific criteria for judging whether or not an objective has been met are necessary to make objectives measurable, and thus useful.

termShortDefinition: A series of steps followed in a definite order to arrive at a result.
termExtendedDefinition: A procedure defines the tasks that need to be completed, and their order, but does not specify the exact actions that make up each step.  In other words, the same procedure can be completed several times, and could look slightly different each time, even producing different results.  In this sense it is somewhat open-ended, but also has some predictability and control.

termShortDefinition: A means of getting money for a project.
termExtendedDefinition: Projects may have multiple funding sources, and funding sources may take a variety of forms.  Taxes, fees, donations, investments by individuals, groups, or corporations, et cetera, are all examples of funding sources.

termShortDefinition: A temporary undertaking requiring concerted effort.
termExtendedDefinition: The defining features of a project are that it requires directed effort, and has some end point at which it will stop. In the realm of transportation planning, the term is often used to describe government or community-sponsored efforts to build, repair, or study something.

termShortDefinition: A broad geographical area that is considered as a unit for the user\'s purpose.
termExtendedDefinition: Regions can be of any size, but are usually made up of contiguous areas.  The locations that make up a region are often loosely-defined, chosen to reflect geographic or cultural similarities, or to express the area of interest of some group or organization.  For this reason, it is not always possible to say exactly where a region begins and ends.

termShortDefinition: An outline of an expected sequence of events
termExtendedDefinition: A scenario describes what might happen, or what is expected to happen, but not what has to happen.  It is different from a procedure in that it is less rigid; whereas a procedure contains steps that must each be engaged, and their order, the scenario only sets up a situation, and then relinquishes control.

termShortDefinition: Something a person cares deeply about
termExtendedDefinition: A value is something (usually a principle or quality) that has intrinsic merit for a particular person.  That is, they consider it to be worth having regardless of whether or not it has other benefits.  They are basic desires and drives which govern behavior.  Values in this sense are highly abstract, and to be useful in decision making, they must be framed in terms of some specific goals which embody them.
termSource1: Drew & Nyerges, Journal of Risk Research 2004, p 44.

termShortDefinition: A particular environment, or walk of life.
termExtendedDefinition: Describes things which fall under the same sphere, in a very broad sense.  For example, a \"social\" domain would include everything about our casual and intimate relations with other people in society, a \"business\" domain would include everything related to our dealings in work and commerce.  While the usefulness of a domain is in distinguishing between categories of things, domains, in practice, often overlap.

termShortDefinition: A tally indicating how often something has occured.
termExtendedDefinition: Scores are given to record when or how often some criterion has been met.  Can be measured either absolutely or in comparison to a standard, for instance on a scale of 1 to 10.

termShortDefinition: A strong liking of one thing over its alternatives.
termExtendedDefinition: Also, the act of choosing one thing over its alternatives.

termShortDefinition: A measure of the heaviness of an object, or the relative importance given to something.
termExtendedDefinition: A number of factors may be considered in decision making, but they may not all carry equal weight in terms of determining the final outcome.  Different factors have different weights, and this changes their ultimate importance to the decision.  Weight is assigned according to the situation, and is not inherent to any factor.

termShortDefinition: The position of a person, place or thing in relation to others based on a property they all share.
The minimum acceptable level of attainment of a criteria.
A group of people actively working towards a specific goal on a specific issue.
The process of allowing government agencies review and comment on transportation proposals
A measure of the degree to which air is free from pollutants.
termExtendedDefinition: Air quality is often measured with the Environmental Protection Agency锞s AQI (Air Quality Index), which considers air pollutants to be almost any substance, natural or artificial, which has the potential to become airborne.  On the AQI scale, pollutants are counted and measured in parts per billion.

termShortDefinition: An elevated section of SR-99, running along the waterfront in downtown Seattle.
termExtendedDefinition: Many consider the existing viaduct to be aging and potentially unsafe in the event of an earthquake, and the issue of its replacement has been hotly debated.

termShortDefinition: A policy question that is to be voted on by ordinary citizens, rather than by the legislature.
termExtendedDefinition: The state constitution allows for questions of policy to be given directly to the electorate.  The ballot measure will come about in several ways, for instance from a citizen initiative, or a legislative referendum.  A ballot measure may be binding or non-binding.

termShortDefinition: Providing some features and practices that aid in the safe and convenient use of bicycles in transportation
termExtendedDefinition: Some features of a bicycle-friendly area include bike lanes, designated covered areas for bicycle parking, safety education for motorists and bicyclists, police enforcement of bicyclists' rights, and others.

termShortDefinition: A designated section of an existing road where bicyclists have right-of-way.
termExtendedDefinition: Also known (in the United States) as a Class 2 bikeway.

termShortDefinition: A certificate issued by a government or corporation to raise funds.  The cost of the bond is promised to be repaid later, usually with interest.
A fee required for passage over a bridge.
termExtendedDefinition: Sometimes used to control traffic flow (based on the theory that, in order to pay the fee, some drivers will find alternate routes), but most often they are used to raise revenue.

termShortDefinition: A network of bus routes operating mostly in separate lanes from vehicular traffic.
termExtendedDefinition: Bus rapid transit is a type of rapid transit in which buses travel in dedicated lanes in which they generally have exclusive right-of-way, and generally fewer stops compared to other types of transit systems.  There is no single, specific way in which a Bus Rapid Transit system must be implemented, and existing systems make use of everything from separa

termShortDefinition: A method of regular travel not dependent upon single occupancy vehicle usage.
termExtendedDefinition: Common commuting alternatives include transit, carpooling, walking, bicycling, and others.  The 锞alternative锞17 in this case is to single occupancy vehicle commuting, for instance when one person drives to and from work in a car.

termShortDefinition: Separate, even mutually-exclusive efforts to address the same transportation issue.
Provisions made to assist people with disabilities in using some aspect of the transportation system.
termExtendedDefinition: The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 states that it is illegal to discriminate on the basis of a disability, and this is taken to legally guarantee that reasonable accomodations will be made to aid in the use of the transportation system.  Disability access features can include elevator ramps on buses, audio signals at crosswalks, and others.

termShortDefinition: Development in the economy of a region.
termExtendedDefinition: Usually (but not necessarily) implies the improvement of a regional economy, to the benefit of its citizens.

termShortDefinition: A measure of the number of people employed in a predefined location.
termExtendedDefinition: Usually, employment density is measured either in parcel density, which is the number of employees in a given area of land (for instance, acres, blocks, or square miles), or in building density, which is essentially its opposite (the amount of space there is for each worker in a particular area).   It is a measurement of how efficiently an area of land is being used commercially, and can help in transportation planning by (for instance) informing how streets and bus routes are planned around commuting traffic.

termShortDefinition: An analysis of the environmental impacts of proposed land development and transportation projects.
termExtendedDefinition: Sometimes called an Enviromental Impact Report (EIR) or Environmental Impact Statement.  They are usually prepared prior to making a final decision about development of, and a draft of the study will be circulated for public notice and commentary.  Generally, impact studies discuss how construction, production, or development on a project will affect the environment (positively and negatively) of the area in question.

termShortDefinition: The degree  to which transportation services are distributed appropriately and fairly.
termExtendedDefinition: Transportation equity depends on how a particular group of people are effected by transportation services, either positively or negatively.  Transportation equity depends greatly on the population being considered 锞17 services that are thought to be equitably distributed in one group (for instance, a social or economic group) may be recognized as less equitable in another.  The Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA 锞17 21) provides federal money to help aid in assuring transportation equity.

termShortDefinition: A federal agency responsible for providing funding assistance for transit services.
termExtendedDefinition: (Or FTA) Formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Administration (UMTA); FTA is the agency of the U.S. Department of Transportation which administers the federal program of financial assistance to public transit. (APTA)

termShortDefinition: The ways in which money for transportation projects can be raised or alloted.
termExtendedDefinition: Includes money from the existing general tax fund, as well as new taxes, bonds, levies, tolls, et cetera.  May also refer to private investments in some cases. Funding options may also be of various durations and schedules, from immediate to long-term.

termShortDefinition: A set of funds for a particular project.
termExtendedDefinition: A funding package is a fixed or variable amount of capital given or set aside for a particular project.

termShortDefinition: A sales tax applied to fuel.
termExtendedDefinition: A gas tax is a specific tax applied to the sale of fuel, usually gasoline at a filling station.  Fuel is taxed at a fixed rate based on the amount sold.  The money raised from the tax is almost always allocated to transportation-related projects (often the maintenance and construction of roads).

termShortDefinition: A type of activism involving the participation of a community network of non-professional activists.
termExtendedDefinition: Grassroots activism usually begins at a local level, with a small community of interested, "ordinary" citizens, rather than with an existing group, or professional activists.

termShortDefinition: The use of specific techniques to ensure that the type, amount, and rate of development adheres to community known community goals.
termExtendedDefinition: Growth management techniques aim to make sure that the needs of a population will be met by the amount of services a city can provide, regardless of how that population grows.  A growth management plan might call for zoning regulations that control the number of particular types of businesses in different parts of a city, or for impact fees that fund the creation of new parks, schools, transportation projects, etc.

termShortDefinition: The number of cars a highway is expected to handle in a given length of time.
termExtendedDefinition: Usually, highway capacity is measured in cars per hour under normal weather and traffic flow conditions.

termShortDefinition: Designated lanes or roadways for vehicles with numerous passengers, or for single occupancy vehicles that have paid a usage fee.
The number of homes in a given area.
A section of interstate highway passing through eastern King County
termExtendedDefinition: Also called the Renton Freeway.  I-405 bypasses downtown Seattle, and is heavily used by Eastside commuters.

termShortDefinition: A group composed of representatives from each district who act as legislators in county government.
termExtendedDefinition: Also called the Metropolitan King County Council.  Currently has 13 members, responsible for enacting laws, policies, and setting an annual budget.

termShortDefinition: A part of county government responsible for operating the Metro transit system and maintaining roads.
termExtendedDefinition: KC-DOT is responsible for other services, such as the operation of King County International Airport (Boeing Field) and the maintenance of city vehicles.

termShortDefinition: A tram or trolley for mass transit that uses existing city streets, with some right-of-way.
termExtendedDefinition: Light rail is called "light" in order to distinguish it from other rail systems that carry more passengers, and require more exclusive infrastructure (monorails and passenger trains, for instance).  Light rail generally shares the streets with pedestrians, buses, and automobiles, but has right-of-way for some or all of its length.  Light rail cars are usually powered by electricity from overhead cables.

termShortDefinition: A community designed with the needs of residents in mind.
termExtendedDefinition: Communities representing a holistic approach to how cities are planned, designed and built, by giving proper attention to the involvement of people in the planning of neighborhoods; adopting appropriate planning principles; and designing buildings, streets and other transportation facilities to meet the needs of the people.

termShortDefinition: The result of the process of developing and discussing a city's official transportation strategy
The ways in which large quantities of material can be transported in to, out of, and through a city
termExtendedDefinition: Includes truck, rail, and marine freight movement.

termShortDefinition: Various ways in which a set of events can effect a neighborhood
termExtendedDefinition: A general term for the effects of a project, event, or other phenomena.  There is no single list of ways in which neighborhoods can be impacted, but rising or falling crime rates, housing prices, and population are common examples.  Often, the ways in which a particular neighborhood have been or could be effected by a project are made into a Neighborhood Impact Statement.

termShortDefinition: Unwanted sound, usually man-made
termExtendedDefinition: Sound is considered to be noise pollution when it is louder than the ambient environmental sound in an area, and when it has some negative effect on listeners.  Sound that is loud, persistent, and uncontrollable is a good example of what would be considered noise pollution.  Automobiles, electronics, factories, air conditioners, barking dogs, concerts, and air conditioners are common sources of noise pollution, but this is by no means an exhaustive list.

termShortDefinition: A person who travels on foot or who uses assistive devices, such as a wheelchair, for mobility.
Aspects of the design and implementation of a project that arise from the general public
termExtendedDefinition: Public involvement might take the form of community meetings where transportation proposals are explained and comments are sought out by officials, considered, and included in a revised proposal.

termShortDefinition: The federally-mandated regional transportation agency for the central Puget Sound region.
termExtendedDefinition: The PSRC is a forum for state agencies and county, tribal, and municipal representatives to discuss issues related to transportation planning and economic development in the region.  The PSRC is also responsible for funding some transportation projects that accord with its long-term transportation plan.

termShortDefinition: An issue to be voted on by citizens rather than legislators.
termExtendedDefinition: The state constitution specifies that any registered voter may demand, by process of petition, that any non-emergency legislative act be verified by voter approval prior to going into effect.  Voter referendums may also come directly from the state legislature.

termShortDefinition: An arterial street that accommodate the movement of large amounts of freight and heavytrucks.

termExtendedDefinition: An analysis of the engineering and financial feasibility of alternatives under consideration for a rail extension or other major transit construction project; required before federal monies can be allocated to a project.
An interest group based in Washington, D.C., whose membership is fairly obvious from the name. Involved in research, advocacy and technical assistance.

termName: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials
termExtendedDefinition: An interest group based in Washington, D.C., whose membership is fairly obvious from the name. Involved in research, advocacy and technical assistance.
The extent to which facilities are barrier free and useable by persons with disabilities, including wheelchair users.

Federal civil rights legislation for disabled persons passed in 1990; calls on public transit systems to make their services more fully accessible as well as to underwrite a parallel network of paratransit service.

Federal civil rights legislation for disabled persons passed in 1990; calls on public transit systems to make their services more fully accessible as well as to underwrite a parallel network of paratransit service.
A bus introduced in 1977 that incorporates new styling and design features compared to previous buses.

An electric system of aerial cables with suspended unpowered passenger vehicles. The vehicles are propelled by separate cables attached to the vehicle suspension system and powered by engines or motors at a central location not on board the vehicle.

Low-polluting fuels which are used to propel a vehicle instead of high-sulfur diesel or gasoline. Examples include methanol, ethanol, propane or compressed natural gas, liquid natural gas, low-sulfur or "clean" diesel and electricity.
A major labor union representing workers in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.

The national, nonprofit trade association representing the public transit industry. APTA members include more than 400 public transit systems, as well as state and local departments of transportation and planning agencies, manufacturers and suppliers of transit equipment, consultants, contractors and universities.

The national, nonprofit trade association representing the public transit industry. APTA members include more than 400 public transit systems, as well as state and local departments of transportation and planning agencies, manufacturers and suppliers of transit equipment, consultants, contractors and universities.

Those transportation improvement projects, contained in an area's Transportation Improvement Program (TIP), that are proposed for implementation in the current year. The annual element is submitted to the U.S. Department of Transportation (U.S. DOT) as part of the required planning process.

A federal budgetary term that refers to a statutorily prescribed division or assignment of funds. It is based on prescribed formulas in the law and consists of dividing authorized obligation authority for a specific program among transit systems.

A federal budgetary term that refers to an act of Congress that permits federal agencies to incur obligations and make payments out of the Treasury for specified purposes. An appropriation act is the most common means of providing budget authority, but in some cases the authorization legislation itself provides the budget authority.

Also known as "smart cars," "smart streets" and even "smart buses," it promises to move the daily commute from the era of the Flinstones to the age of the Jetsons, from frustration-filled gridlock to computer guided navigation. The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles. Designed to improve safety and productivity, IVHS also can have a positive impact on air quality by cutting congestion. When the term is applied to transit, it is called APTS; in commercial trucking, it is referred to as CVO. The European especially seem to stretch the limits of the English language to come up with clever names for the nearly endless IVHS programs that have been spawned of late: DRIVE (Dedicated Road Infrastructure for Vehicle Safety in Europe) is a European Community-sponsored IVHS program that contains within it CIDER (Communication Infrastructure for DRIVE on European Roads), PAMELA (Pricing and Monitoring Electronically of Automobiles), PANDORA (Prototyping a Navigation Database of Road Network Attributes) and SOCRATES (System of Cellular Radio for Traffic Efficiency and Safety).

Also known as "smart cars," "smart streets" and even "smart buses," it promises to move the daily commute from the era of the Flinstones to the age of the Jetsons, from frustration-filled gridlock to computer guided navigation. The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles. Designed to improve safety and productivity, IVHS also can have a positive impact on air quality by cutting congestion. When the term is applied to transit, it is called APTS; in commercial trucking, it is referred to as CVO. The European especially seem to stretch the limits of the English language to come up with clever names for the nearly endless IVHS programs that have been spawned of late: DRIVE (Dedicated Road Infrastructure for Vehicle Safety in Europe) is a European Community-sponsored IVHS program that contains within it CIDER (Communication Infrastructure for DRIVE on European Roads), PAMELA (Pricing and Monitoring Electronically of Automobiles), PANDORA (Prototyping a Navigation Database of Road Network Attributes) and SOCRATES (System of Cellular Radio for Traffic Efficiency and Safety).
A method of settling disputes where labor and management present their case to an impartial third party, called an arbitrator, who has the responsibility of deciding the case.
A major thoroughfare, used primarily for through traffic rather than for access to adjacent land, that is characterized by high vehicular capacity and continuity of movement.
A bus usually 55 feet or more in length with two connected passenger compartments that bend at the connecting point when the bus turns a corner.

Now even law-abiding commuters will be able to zoom past the toll takers. Sensors at toll booths will pick up billing information from devices installed in cars, allowing motorists to drive through without stopping; the amount of the toll is automatically deducted from a prepaid account or billed to the vehicle's owner. An application of  AVI  technology.

Now even law-abiding commuters will be able to zoom past the toll takers. Sensors at toll booths will pick up billing information from devices installed in cars, allowing motorists to drive through without stopping; the amount of the toll is automatically deducted from a prepaid account or billed to the vehicle's owner. An application of  AVI  technology.

Now even law-abiding commuters will be able to zoom past the toll takers. Sensors at toll booths will pick up billing information from devices installed in cars, allowing motorists to drive through without stopping; the amount of the toll is automatically deducted from a prepaid account or billed to the vehicle's owner. An application of  AVI  technology.

No more fumbling with the map, no more dreading unknown traffic hazards that lurk ahead of you -- these innovations provide travelers with information to help in trip planning and changing course en route to bypass congestion, e.g., broadcast traffic reports, in-car computerized maps and highway CMSs. Also can include automated transit trip planning and automated rideshare matching.

No more fumbling with the map, no more dreading unknown traffic hazards that lurk ahead of you -- these innovations provide travelers with information to help in trip planning and changing course en route to bypass congestion, e.g., broadcast traffic reports, in-car computerized maps and highway CMSs. Also can include automated transit trip planning and automated rideshare matching.

A high-tech version of the old-fashion traffic cop,  ATMS  uses a variety of means to more efficiently manage traffic. It can include roadside sensors, ramp metering,  HOV  lanes and synchronized traffic signals that respond to traffic flows.

A high-tech version of the old-fashion traffic cop,  ATMS  uses a variety of means to more efficiently manage traffic. It can include roadside sensors, ramp metering,  HOV  lanes and synchronized traffic signals that respond to traffic flows.

Basic, substantive legislation which establishes or continues the legal operation of a federal program or agency, either indefinitely or for a specific period of time, or which sanctions a particular type of obligation or expenditure within a program. An authorization may set appropriation limits. See " Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991 ".

An area in which normal automobile traffic is prohibited or limited to certain times, and vehicular traffic is restricted to public transit, emergency vehicles, taxicabs and, in some cases, delivery of goods.

An area in which normal automobile traffic is prohibited or limited to certain times, and vehicular traffic is restricted to public transit, emergency vehicles, taxicabs and, in some cases, delivery of goods.
An electric railway operating without vehicle operators or other crew on board the vehicle.

A system of controls and equipment that automatically admits passengers on insertion of the correct fare in coins, tokens, tickets or farecards; it may include special equipment for transporting and counting revenues.

A system of controls and equipment that automatically admits passengers on insertion of the correct fare in coins, tokens, tickets or farecards; it may include special equipment for transporting and counting revenues.
Technology that tracks the current location of fleet vehicles to assist in dispatching, maintaining schedules, answering specific customer inquiries, etc.
Technology that tracks the current location of fleet vehicles to assist in dispatching, maintaining schedules, answering specific customer inquiries, etc.

New techniques to ease stresses and strains of driving are evolving, possibly leading to the day when you may be able to sit back and leave your car in charge. AVCS spans the gamut from ordinary cruise control to "smart cruise control" that helps maintain safe following distance to, researchers hope, "platooning" -- the ability to electronically link and guide a dense pack of cars moving in formation at high speed.

New techniques to ease stresses and strains of driving are evolving, possibly leading to the day when you may be able to sit back and leave your car in charge. AVCS spans the gamut from ordinary cruise control to "smart cruise control" that helps maintain safe following distance to, researchers hope, "platooning" -- the ability to electronically link and guide a dense pack of cars moving in formation at high speed.
It combines an in-car device as well as a roadside receiver that will identify for vehicles for purposes of automated toll collection, stolen vehicle recovery, etc.
It combines an in-car device as well as a roadside receiver that will identify for vehicles for purposes of automated toll collection, stolen vehicle recovery, etc.

Employs satellites and other technologies to track vehicles in a fleet, assisting with dispatching and other applications. Currently used by truckers and courier services, it could be used in the future by transit systems to provide real-time schedule information for patrons, and will help the  CHP  monitor FSP tow trucks.

Employs satellites and other technologies to track vehicles in a fleet, assisting with dispatching and other applications. Currently used by truckers and courier services, it could be used in the future by transit systems to provide real-time schedule information for patrons, and will help the  CHP  monitor FSP tow trucks.
The number of people on the road divided by the number of cars on the road.
The number of people on the road divided by the number of cars on the road.

The ratio of all people traveling by any mode, including cars, buses, trains and bicycles (or telecommuting), in a given area during a given time period to the number of cars on the road. A key measure of the efficiency and effectiveness of a transportation network - the higher the AVR, the better you're doing in terms of energy consumption and air pollution.

The ratio of all people traveling by any mode, including cars, buses, trains and bicycles (or telecommuting), in a given area during a given time period to the number of cars on the road. A key measure of the efficiency and effectiveness of a transportation network - the higher the AVR, the better you're doing in terms of energy consumption and air pollution.

A labor union designated by an appropriate government agency or recognized by the employer as the exclusive representative of all employees in the bargaining unit for purposes of collective bargaining.
The period between the morning and evening peak periods when transit service is generally scheduled on a constant interval. Also known as "off-peak period".
The price charged to one adult for one transit ride; excludes transfer charges, zone charges, express service charges, peak period surcharges and reduced fares.
Arbitration with a final and binding award, which is often enforceable in the courts.
A federal budgetary term that refers to legal authority given by Congress to federal agencies to make funds available for obligation or expenditure.

A federal budgetary term that refers to a concurrent resolution passed by both Houses of Congress, but not requiring the signature of the President, setting forth the congressional budget for each of five fiscal years. The budget resolution sets forth various budget total and functional allocations, and may include reconciliation instructions to designated House or Senate committees.

A rubber-tired, self-propelled, manually-steered vehicle with fuel supply carried on board the vehicle. Types include advanced design, articulated, charter, circulator, double deck, express, feeder, intercity, medium-size, new look, sightseeing, small, standard-size, subscription, suburban, transit and van.
A bus introduced in 1977 that incorporates new styling and design features compared to previous buses.
A bus transporting a group of persons who, pursuant to a common purpose, and under a single contract at a fixed price, have acquired the exclusive use of a bus to travel together under an itinerary.
A bus serving an area confined to a specific locale, such as a downtown area or suburban neighborhood with connections to major traffic corridors.
A bus with two separate passenger compartments, one above the other.
A bus with two separate passenger compartments, one above the other.
A bus that operates a portion of the route without stops or with a limited number of stops.
A bus service that picks up and delivers passengers to a rail rapid transit station or express bus stop or terminal.
A bus with front doors only, high-backed seats, separate luggage compartments, and usually with restroom facilities for use in high-speed long-distance service.
A bus from 29 to 34 feet in length.
A bus with the predominant styling and mechanical equipment common to buses manufactured between 1959 and 1978.
A bus adapted for sightseeing use, usually with expanded window areas.
A bus 28 feet or less in length.
A bus from 35 to 41 feet in length.
A commuter bus express service operated for a guaranteed number of patrons from a given area on a prepaid, reserved-seat basis.
A bus with front doors only, normally with high-backed seats, and without luggage compartments or restroom facilities for use in longer-distance service with relatively few stops.
A bus with front and center doors, normally with a rear-mounted engine, low-back seating, and without luggage compartments or restroom facilities for use in frequent-stop service.

An electric, rubber-tired transit vehicle, manually steered, propelled by a motor drawing current through overhead wires from a central power source not on board the vehicle. Also known as "trolley coach" or "trackless trolley".

A 20-foot long or shorter vehicle, usually with an automotive-type engine and limited seating normally entered directly through side or rear doors rather than from a central aisle, used for demand response, vanpool, and lightly patronized motorbus service.

Federal funding granted under Section 3 of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act). These discretionary funds are used for bus-related construction projects or to replace, rehabilitate or purchase buses.
A street or highway lane intended primarily for buses, either all day or during specified periods, but sometimes also used by carpools meeting requirements set out in traffic laws.
A building or other structure constructed near a bus stop, to provide seating and protection from the weather for the convenience of waiting passengers.
A place where passengers can board or alight from the bus, usually identified by a sign.
Exclusive freeway lane for buses and carpools.

Federal legislation that sets national air quality standards; requires each state with areas that have not met federal air quality standards to prepare a SIP. The sweeping 1990 amendments to the CAA, sometimes referred to as CAAA , established new air quality requirements for the development of metropolitan transportation plans and programs.

Federal legislation that sets national air quality standards; requires each state with areas that have not met federal air quality standards to prepare a SIP. The sweeping 1990 amendments to the CAA, sometimes referred to as CAAA , established new air quality requirements for the development of metropolitan transportation plans and programs.

Clean Air Act Amends of 1990.  The comprehensive federal legislation which establishes criteria for attaining and maintaining the federal standards for allowable concentrations and exposure limits for various air pollutants; the act also provides emission standards for specific vehicles and fuels.

An electric railway operating in mixed street traffic with unpowered, individually-controlled transit vehicles propelled by moving cables located below the street surface and powered by engines or motors at a central location not on board the vehicle.
Financial assistance for transit capital expenses (not operating costs); such aid may originate with federal, local or state governments.
Costs of long-term assets of a public transit system such as property, buildings, vehicles, etc.
Monies dedicated for new projects to cover one-time costs, such as construction of roads, transit lines and facilities or purchase of buses and rail cars.
An arrangement where two or more people share the use and cost of privately owned automobiles in traveling to and from pre-arranged destinations together.
An overhead contact wire system which supplies power from a central power source to an electric vehicle (such as a trolley bus; see "Bus, Trolley".
The downtown retail trade and commercial area of a city or an area of very high land valuation, traffic flow, and concentration of retail business offices, theaters, hotels and services.
The downtown retail trade and commercial area of a city or an area of very high land valuation, traffic flow, and concentration of retail business offices, theaters, hotels and services.
An investment program intended to enhance performance of a transportation process, part of the RTIP
An investment program intended to enhance performance of a transportation process, part of the RTIP
A clean-burning alternative fuel for vehicles.
A clean-burning alternative fuel for vehicles.
An increase or decrease in employees' wages or salaries made on the basis of changes in agreed-upon economic indices, usually the Consumer Price Index.
An increase or decrease in employees' wages or salaries made on the basis of changes in agreed-upon economic indices, usually the Consumer Price Index.
Negotiations between labor union representatives and employers to reach agreement on a contract describing such matters as wages, hours and working conditions.
A person who travels regularly between home and work or school.
Arbitration that is required by law.
Efforts by an impartial third party to encourage agreement between a labor union and management by counseling each side and facilitating negotiations. Also known as "mediation锞17.

The ongoing process that ensures the planning for highway and transit systems, as a whole and over the long term, is consistent with the state air quality plans for attaining and maintaining health-based air quality standards; conformity is determined by metropolitan planning organizations  (MPOs)  and the U.S. Department of Transportation ( U.S. DOT ), and is based on whether transportation plans and programs meet the provisions of a State Implementation Plan.  To achieve conformity with federal clean air requirements, transportation projects collectively must not worsen air quality.

A federal budgetary term that refers to a form of budget authority permitting obligations to be incurred in advance of appropriations. Advance obligations, however, have been limited by the appropriations committees with obligation limitations.
Reserved lane for buses on which the direction of bus traffic is opposite to the flow of traffic on the other lanes.
A broad geographical band that follows a general directional flow connecting major sources of trips that may contain a number of streets, highways and transit route alignments.
Non-radial bus or rail service which does not enter the Central Business District

A business owned and operated by one or more socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. Socially and economically disadvantaged individuals include African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Native Americans, Asian Pacific Americans or Asian Indian Americans and any other minorities or individuals found to be disadvantaged by the Small Business Administration under Section 8(a) of the Small Business Act.

A business owned and operated by one or more socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. Socially and economically disadvantaged individuals include African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Native Americans, Asian Pacific Americans or Asian Indian Americans and any other minorities or individuals found to be disadvantaged by the Small Business Administration under Section 8(a) of the Small Business Act.
The movement of a transit vehicle without passengers aboard; often to and from a garage or to and from one route to another.
A source of monies which by law is available for use only to support a specific purpose, and cannot be diverted to other uses.
Non-fixed-route service utilizing vans or buses with passengers boarding and alighting at pre-arranged times at any location within the system's service area. Also called "Dial-a-Ride".
Non-fixed-route service utilizing vans or buses with passengers boarding and alighting at pre-arranged times at any location within the system's service area. Also called "Demand Responsive锞17

A federal budgetary terms that refers to any funds whose distribution in not automatic. Discretionary spending encompasses programs controlled by annual appropriations bills and is subject to the constraints imposed by the discretionary spending limits set in the balanced budget law.

At the federal level, a cabinet agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation. The DOT includes the  FHWA  , the  FTA  and the  FAA , among others. There are also state DOTs. (Washington锞s is called WashDOT)

At the federal level, a cabinet agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation. The DOT includes the  FHWA  , the  FTA  and the  FAA , among others. There are also state DOTs. (Washington锞s is called WashDOT)
A period during which a vehicle is inoperative because of repairs or maintenance.
A type of automated guideway transit vehicle operating on a loop or shuttle route within the Central Business District ( CBD ) of a city.
A type of automated guideway transit vehicle operating on a loop or shuttle route within the Central Business District ( CBD ) of a city.
The scheduled time a vehicle or train is allowed to discharge and take on passengers at a stop, including opening and closing doors.

A federal budgetary term that refers to the specific designation by Congress that part of a more general lump-sum appropriation be used for a particular project; the earmark can be designated as a minimum and/or maximum dollar amount.
A ratio of appropriated dollars between Sections 9 and 18 (formula funds) to Section 3 (discretionary funds).

Someone designated by a business or organization to assist its workers with forming carpools and vanpools, plotting their commute by public transit, and the like. Otherwise known as an SOV-buster, and definitely a career with growth potential the 1990s and beyond.

Someone designated by a business or organization to assist its workers with forming carpools and vanpools, plotting their commute by public transit, and the like. Otherwise known as an SOV-buster, and definitely a career with growth potential the 1990s and beyond.
An alternative fuel; a liquid alcohol fuel with vapor heavier than air; produced from agricultural products such as corn, grain and sugar cane.
A highway or other facility that can only be used by buses or other transit vehicles.

A presidential directive that furnishes guidance to federal agencies for cooperation with state and local governments in the evaluation, review and coordination of federal assistance programs and projects.
Measure of the proportion of operating expenses covered by passenger fares; found by dividing fare box revenue by total operating expenses for each mode and/or systemwide.
Value of cash, tickets, tokens and pass receipts given by passengers as payment for rides; excludes charter revenue.
The extent to which ridership responds to fare increases or decreases.
The system set up to determine how much is to be paid by various passengers using a transit vehicle at any given time.
A boat providing fixed-route service across a body of water.
When you don't do your SIP as required by the CAA, you get "FIPped," which means the feds step in and do one for you.
When you don't do your SIP as required by the CAA, you get "FIPped," which means the feds step in and do one for you.
An indirect cost that remains relatively constant, irrespective of the level of operational activity.

A system of vehicles that can operate only on its own guideway constructed for that purpose (e.g., rapid rail, light rail). Federal usage in funding legislation also includes exclusive right-of-way bus operations, trolley coaches and ferryboats as "fixed guideway" transit.

Service provided on a repetitive, fixed-schedule basis along a specific route with vehicles stopping to pick up and deliver passengers to specific locations; each fixed-route trip serves the same origins and destinations, unlike demand responsive and taxicabs.

Unlike funding that flows only to highways or only to transit by a rigid formula, this is money that can be invested on a range of transportation projects. Examples of flexible funding programs include the Surface Transportation Program, Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement, and Flexible Congestion Relief.

Those federal funds which can be used for highway, transit or other transportation projects, as decided by regional Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPOs) and state governments. Examples of such funds are the Surface Transportation Program (STP) and the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality (CMAQ) fund.

Funds distributed or apportioned to qualifying recipients on the basis of formulas described in law; e.g., funds in the Section 18 program for Small Urban and Rural Transit Assistance, which are distributed to each state based on the state's percentage of national rural population.
An area for parking usually located outside the Central Business District (CBD) and most often used by suburban residents who work or shop downtown.

The yearly accounting period for the federal government which begins October 1 and ends on the following September 30. The fiscal year is designated by the calendar year in which it ends (e.g., FY 06 is from October 1, 2005 to September 30, 2006).

The process of resolving a labor dispute involving the application or interpretation of a collective bargaining agreement, by asking an impartial third party to make a decision after both labor and management have presented their cases.

"Chains required on Snoqualmie pass." Sound familiar? It may not be a top 20 hit, but such radio warnings broadcast via a special frequency are music to the ears of drivers who want to prepare for, avoid altogether, hazardous or difficult road conditions ahead.

"Chains required on Snoqualmie Summit." Sound familiar? It may not be a top 20 hit, but such radio warnings broadcast via a special frequency are music to the ears of drivers who want to prepare for, avoid altogether, hazardous or difficult road conditions ahead.
Time interval between vehicles moving in the same direction on a particular route.

The federal trust fund established by the Highway Revenue Act of 1956; this fund has two accounts -- the Highway Account and the Mass Transit Account. Trust fund revenues are derived from federal highway-user taxes and fees such as motor fuel taxes; trust fund uses and expenditures are determined by law.
The process of arriving at the terms of a new collective bargaining agreement, by asking an impartial third party to make rulings after both labor and management have presented their cases.

Those issues or activities which involve or affect more than one mode of transportation, including transportation connections, choices, cooperation and coordination of various modes.  The term "mode" is used to refer to and to distinguish from each other the various forms of transportation, such as automobile, transit, ship, bicycle and walking. Intermodal refers specifically to the connections between modes.

This landmark $151 billion legislation signed into law in December 1991 proposes broad changes to the way transportation decisions are made. In the words of the STPP folks, it emphasizes diversity and balance of modes, as well as the preservation of existing systems over construction of new facilities, especially roads.

This landmark $151 billion legislation signed into law in December 1991 proposes broad changes to the way transportation decisions are made. In the words of the STPP folks, it emphasizes diversity and balance of modes, as well as the preservation of existing systems over construction of new facilities, especially roads.

Also known as "smart cars," "smart streets" and even "smart buses," it promises to move the daily commute from the era of the Flinstones to the age of the Jetsons, from frustration-filled gridlock to computer guided navigation. The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles. Designed to improve safety and productivity, IVHS also can have a positive impact on air quality by cutting congestion. When the term is applied to transit, it is called APTS; in commercial trucking, it is referred to as CVO. The European especially seem to stretch the limits of the English language to come up with clever names for the nearly endless IVHS programs that have been spawned of late: DRIVE (Dedicated Road Infrastructure for Vehicle Safety in Europe) is a European Community-sponsored IVHS program that contains within it CIDER (Communication Infrastructure for DRIVE on European Roads), PAMELA (Pricing and Monitoring Electronically of Automobiles), PANDORA (Prototyping a Navigation Database of Road Network Attributes) and SOCRATES (System of Cellular Radio for Traffic Efficiency and Safety).

Also known as "smart cars," "smart streets" and even "smart buses," it promises to move the daily commute from the era of the Flinstones to the age of the Jetsons, from frustration-filled gridlock to computer guided navigation. The term refers to a wide range of advanced electronics and communications technology applied to roads and vehicles. Designed to improve safety and productivity, IVHS also can have a positive impact on air quality by cutting congestion. When the term is applied to transit, it is called APTS; in commercial trucking, it is referred to as CVO. The European especially seem to stretch the limits of the English language to come up with clever names for the nearly endless IVHS programs that have been spawned of late: DRIVE (Dedicated Road Infrastructure for Vehicle Safety in Europe) is a European Community-sponsored IVHS program that contains within it CIDER (Communication Infrastructure for DRIVE on European Roads), PAMELA (Pricing and Monitoring Electronically of Automobiles), PANDORA (Prototyping a Navigation Database of Road Network Attributes) and SOCRATES (System of Cellular Radio for Traffic Efficiency and Safety).
Privately-owned, small or medium-sized vehicle usually operated on a fixed route but not on a fixed schedule.
Ventures undertaken by the public and private sectors for development of land around transit stations or stops.
A place where commuters are driven and dropped off at a station to board a public transportation vehicle.
Time built into a schedule between arrival at the end of a route and the departure for the return trip, used for the recovery of delays and preparation for the return trip.

A balanced approach to federal funding proportions for highway projects and transit projects; may also refer to employee transportation benefits so that the monthly, tax-free value of a transit pass is equal to that of a parking space; generally, any situation in which transit and highways receive equal treatment in federal funding and other federal procedures.

An alternative fuel; a natural gas cooled to below its boiling point of -260 degrees Fahrenheit so that it becomes a liquid; stored in a vacuum bottle-type container at very low temperatures and under moderate pressure. LNG vapor is lighter than air.

An alternative fuel; a natural gas cooled to below its boiling point of -260 degrees Fahrenheit so that it becomes a liquid; stored in a vacuum bottle-type container at very low temperatures and under moderate pressure. LNG vapor is lighter than air.
The ratio of passengers actually carried versus the total passenger capacity of a vehicle.

Fixed guideway transportation mode that typically operates on city streets and draws it electric power from overhead wires; include streetcars, trolley cars and tramways. Differs from heavy rail -- which has a separated right of way, and includes commuter and intercity rail -- in that it has lighter passenger capacity per hour and more closely spaced stops.

Fixed guideway transportation mode that typically operates on city streets and draws it electric power from overhead wires; include streetcars, trolley cars and tramways. Differs from heavy rail -- which has a separated right of way, and includes commuter and intercity rail -- in that it has lighter passenger capacity per hour and more closely spaced stops.
Fancy name for streetcar.
Fancy name for streetcar.
This technology permits trains to move at high speed above a guideway on a cushion of air generated by magnetic force.

Transit systems which expand their role to include services and approaches beyond traditional public transportation to include ridesharing, high occupancy vehicle programs, public education on transit's benefits and integration of land use, air quality and transportation decisions; the phrase was developed as part of the industry's Transit 2000 policy effort undertaken in the late 1980s and early 1990s.

Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis. Also known as "mass transportation," and "transit".

The federal account, established by the Surface Transportation Assistance Act of 1982, into which a designated portion of the federal Highway Trust Fund revenue from motor fuel taxes is placed (1.5 cents in 1994). This account is used for federal mass transportation assistance.

Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis. Also known as "mass transit" and "transit".
A business owned and operated by one or more individuals who are defined as minorities under U.S. Department of Transportation regulations. See also "disadvantaged business enterprise".
A business owned and operated by one or more individuals who are defined as minorities under U.S. Department of Transportation regulations. See also "disadvantaged business enterprise".
The average distance in miles that a transit vehicle travels before failure of a vital component forces removal of that vehicle from service.
The average distance in miles that a transit vehicle travels before failure of a vital component forces removal of that vehicle from service.
Efforts by an impartial third party to encourage agreement between a labor union and management by counseling each side and facilitating negotiations. Also known as "conciliation".
An alternative fuel; a liquid alcohol fuel with vapor heavier than air; primarily produced from natural gas.

A term which describes how many people use alternative forms of transportation. Frequently used to describe the percentage of people using private automobiles as opposed to the percentage using public transportation.

An analytical tool (often mathematical) used by transportation planners to assist in making forecasts of land use, economic activity, travel activity and their effects on the quality of resources such as land, air and water.
An electric railway in which a rail car or train of cars is suspended from or straddles a guideway formed by a single beam or rail. Most monorails are either heavy rail or automated guideway systems.
A federally required transportation planning body responsible for the RTP and the TIP in its region; the governor designates an MPO in every urbanized area with a population of over 50,000.
A federally required transportation planning body responsible for the RTP and the TIP in its region; the governor designates an MPO in every urbanized area with a population of over 50,000.

Refers to the availability of multiple transportation options, especially within a system or corridor. A concept embraced in ISTEA, a multimodal approach to transportation planning focuses on the most efficient way of getting people or goods from place to place, be it by truck, train, bicycle, automobile, airplane, bus, boat, foot or even a computer modem.
The nationwide organization for MPOs, COGs and other such entities; based in Washington, D.C.
The nationwide organization for MPOs, COGs and other such entities; based in Washington, D.C.

Federal funding granted under Section 3(i) of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act). These discretionary funds are made available for construction of a new fixed guideway system or extension of any existing fixed guideway system, based on cost-effectiveness, alternatives analysis results and the degree of local financial commitment.

An approximately 155,000-mile, still-to-be-designated network brewed in  ISTEA  to provide an interconnected system of principal routes to serve major travel destinations and population centers. Picks up where the Interstate Highway System left off.

An approximately 155,000-mile, still-to-be-designated network brewed in  ISTEA  to provide an interconnected system of principal routes to serve major travel destinations and population centers. Picks up where the Interstate Highway System left off.

Any geographic region of the United States that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has designated as not attaining the federal air quality standards for one or more air pollutants, such as ozone and carbon monoxide.

An intermodal system consisting of all forms of transportation in a unified, interconnected manner to reduce energy consumption and air pollution while promoting economic development and supporting the Nation's preeminent position in international commerce. The NTS includes the National Highway System (NHS), public transportation and access to ports and airports.

Called for in the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, the NTS to date is a proposal by the U.S. Transportation Secretary to integrate all aspects and modes of the transportation system into a single national system. The National Highway System is expected to be a subset of the larger, multimodal NTS.

A federal budgetary term that refers to a binding agreement that will result in an outlay; an agreement by the federal government to pay for goods or services immediately or at some future time when the goods or services are delivered. Also known as a "commitment".

A federal budgetary term that refers to a limit placed in appropriations bills on the amount of federal assistance that may be obligated during a specified time period. It does not affect the scheduled apportionment or allocation of funds; it just controls the rate at which these funds may be used.
Non-rush periods of the day when travel activity is generally lower and less transit service is scheduled. Also called "base period".
Financial assistance for transit operating expenses (not capital costs); such aid may originate with federal, local or state governments.
The sum of all operating expenses minus operating revenues.
Monies paid in salaries, wages, materials, supplies and equipment in order to maintain equipment and buildings, operate vehicles, rent equipment and facilities and settle claims.

Monies used to fund general, day-to-day costs of running transportation systems. For transit, costs include fuel, salaries and replacement parts; for roads, operating costs involve maintaining pavement, filling potholes, paying workers' salaries, and so forth.
Outlay A federal budgetary term that refers to a payment made to meet an obligation; the point at which an actual payment of money is made.
Comparable transportation service required by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 for individuals with disabilities who are unable to use fixed-route transportation systems.
Designated parking areas for automobile drivers who then board transit vehicles from these locations.

A filter which removes a portion of the particulates (solids, soot, etc.) from a vehicle's exhaust stream and generally includes a regenerative unit and associated control system to burn the collected solids.
The total number of miles traveled by passengers on transit vehicles; determined by multiplying the number of unlinked passenger trips times the average length of their trips.
Morning and afternoon time periods when transit riding is heaviest.
The number of vehicles operated in passenger service during the peak period divided by the number operated during the base period.

(1) verb, to assign funds to a project that has been approved by city, state or other agency; (2) noun, a system of funding for implementing transportation projects or policies, such as through the State Transportation Improvement Program (see STIP).
An alternative fuel; a liquid petroleum gas (LPG) which is stored under moderate pressure and with vapor heavier than air; produced as a by-product of natural gas and oil production.

An organization that provides transportation services owned, operated, or subsidized by any municipality, county, regional authority, state, or other governmental agency, including those operated or managed by a private management firm under contract to the government agency owner.

Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis. Also known as "mass transportation," "mass transit" and "transit".

Railroad local and regional passenger train operations between a central city, its suburbs and/or another central city. It may be either locomotive-hauled or self-propelled, and is characterized by multi-trip tickets, specific station-to-station fares, railroad employment practices and usually only one or two stations in the central business district. Also known as "suburban rail".

An electric railway with the capacity for a "heavy volume" of traffic and characterized by exclusive rights-of-way, multi-car trains, high speed and rapid acceleration, sophisticated signaling and high platform loading. Also known as "rapid rail," "subway," "elevated (railway)" or "metropolitan railway (metro)".
A rail transportation system with exclusive right-of-way which serves densely traveled corridors at speeds of 124 miles per hour (200 km/h) and greater.

Federal funding granted under Section 3(h) of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act). These discretionary funds are distributed by a formula and made available to transit systems for improvements on fixed guideway systems that have been in service for at least seven years. Also known as "fixed guideway modernization".
Rail or motorbus transit service operating completely separate from all modes of transportation on an exclusive right-of-way.
A federal budgetary term that refers to the cancellation, in whole or part, of budget authority previously granted by Congress.
Movement in a direction opposite the main flow of traffic, such as from the central city to a suburb during the morning peak period.
A form of transportation, other than public transit, in which more than one person shares the use of the vehicle, such as a van or car, to make a trip. Also known as "carpooling" or "vanpooling".
The number of rides taken by people using a public transportation system in a given time period.
The vehicles used in a transit system, including buses and rail cars.
The total number of miles included in a fixed route transit system network.
The first stop on the way to the STIP, it lists highway and transit and transit projects for which the region hopes to capture  funds.
The first stop on the way to the STIP, it lists highway and transit and transit projects for which the region hopes to capture  funds.

A weighty document, literally and figuratively, it is a multimodal blueprint to guide the region's long-term transportation development. It is based on projections of growth and travel demand coupled with real-world financial assumptions. Required by state and federal law.

A weighty document, literally and figuratively, it is a multimodal blueprint to guide the region's long-term transportation development. It is based on projections of growth and travel demand coupled with real-world financial assumptions. Required by state and federal law.
A state designated agency responsible for preparing the RTP and RTIP; administering TDA and other tasks.
A state designated agency responsible for preparing the RTP and RTIP; administering TDA and other tasks.

The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes grants to public transportation systems in urbanized areas (population greater than 50,000) for both capital and operating programs based on formulas set out in statute.

The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, related to labor protection that is designed to protect transit employees against a worsening of their position with respect to their employment as a result of grant assistance under the Act.

The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes the U.S. Department of Transportation to gather statistical information about the financing and operations of public transportation systems, based upon a uniform system of accounts and records.

The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that declares the national policy to be that elderly persons and persons with disabilities have the same right as other persons to utilize mass transportation facilities and services, and that special efforts shall be made in the planning and design of mass transportation facilities and services so that effective utilization by elderly persons and persons with disabilities is assured.

The subsection of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes grants to nonprofit corporations and associations for the specific purpose of assisting them in providing transportation services meeting the special needs of elderly persons and persons with disabilities for whom mass transportation services are unavailable, insufficient or inappropriate.

The section of the Federal Transit Act (formerly known as the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964), as amended, that authorizes grants to public transit systems outside urbanized areas, based on formulas set out in statute; the funds go initially to the Governor of each state.
A federal budgetary term that refers to the permanent cancellation of budget authority.
A public or private vehicle that travels back and forth over a particular route, especially a short route or one that provides connections between transportation systems, employment centers, etc.

Here's a case where one term refers to two different - albiet related - documents. Metropolitan areas prepare regional SIPs showing steps they plan to take to meet federal air quality standards (outlined in the Clean Air Act). Several SIPs make up the statewide plan for cleaning up the air, also known as a SIP.

Here's a case where one term refers to two different - albeit related - documents. Metropolitan areas prepare regional SIPs showing steps they plan to take to meet federal air quality standards (outlined in the Clean Air Act). Several SIPs make up the statewide plan for cleaning up the air, also known as a SIP.
A vehicle with one occupant, the driver, who is sometimes referred to as a "drive alone."
A vehicle with one occupant, the driver, who is sometimes referred to as a "drive alone."
A nine-year comprehensive plan required of all transit operators by federal and regional transportation funding agencies.
A nine-year comprehensive plan required of all transit operators by federal and regional transportation funding agencies.

A diverse coalition representing transportation, planning, architectural, energy, environmental and historic preservation interests whose goal is to develop a national transportation policy that, in its words, "better serves the environmental, social and economic interests of the nation." A key player in the crafting of ISTEA.

A diverse coalition representing transportation, planning, architectural, energy, environmental and historic preservation interests whose goal is to develop a national transportation policy that, in its words, "better serves the environmental, social and economic interests of the nation." A key player in the crafting of ISTEA.
An act appropriating funds in addition to those in an annual appropriation act because the need for funds is too urgent to be postponed until enactment of the next regular appropriation act.
Strategy to reduce driving or smooth traffic flows in order to cut auto emissions. Required by the Clean Air Act.
Strategy to reduce driving or smooth traffic flows in order to cut auto emissions. Required by the Clean Air Act.
Low-cost ways to reduce demand by automobiles on the transportation system, such as programs to promote telecommuting, flextime and ridesharing.
Low-cost ways to reduce demand by automobiles on the transportation system, such as programs to promote telecommuting, flextime and ridesharing.

An ISTEA created funding category. Ten percent of  STP  monies must be set aside for projects that enhance the compatibility of transportation facilities with their surroundings. Examples of TEA projects include bicycle and pedestrian paths, restoration of rail depots or other historic transportation facilities, acquisition of scenic or open space lands next to travel corridors, and murals or other public art projects.

An ISTEA created funding category. Ten percent of  STP  monies must be set aside for projects that enhance the compatibility of transportation facilities with their surroundings. Examples of TEA projects include bicycle and pedestrian paths, restoration of rail depots or other historic transportation facilities, acquisition of scenic or open space lands next to travel corridors, and murals or other public art projects.

This is primarily a spending plan for federal funding expected to flow to the region from all sources for transportation projects of all types. The TIP is prepared annually with the cooperation of local governments, transit operators and WashDOT. Depending on the funding source it covers a three- to seven-year period.

This is primarily a spending plan for federal funding expected to flow to the region from all sources for transportation projects of all types. The TIP is prepared annually with the cooperation of local governments, transit operators and WashDOT. Depending on the funding source it covers a three- to seven-year period.
A voluntary group set up by employers or other entities to reduce vehicle trips within certain areas.(2) transportation management area
A voluntary group set up by employers or other entities to reduce vehicle trips within certain areas.(2) transportation management area

When it comes to widening a freeway, traffic usually gets a whole lot worse before it gets any better, which is why the feds require a TMP showing how traffic flows will be smoothed or diverted during construction. A TMP might call for installing ramp meters or upgrading parallel roads; boosting public transit service; aggressively marketing carpooling vanpooling; and mounting a public information campaign.
A fixed location where passengers interchange from one route or vehicle to another.

Transportation by bus, rail, or other conveyance, either publicly or privately owned, which provides to the public general or special service on a regular and continuing basis. Also known as "mass transit" and "mass transportation".

An organization (public or private) providing local or regional multi-occupancy-vehicle passenger service. Organizations that provide service under contract to another agency are generally not counted as separate systems.

Funds collected and used by the federal government for carrying out specific purposes and programs according to terms of a trust agreement or statute, such as the Social Security and highway trust funds. Trust funds are administered by the government in a fiduciary capacity and are not available for the general purposes of the government.
Low-cost improvements to make the transportation system work more efficiently, such as traffic signal coordination.
Low-cost improvements to make the transportation system work more efficiently, such as traffic signal coordination.
One of the major labor unions in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.
One of the major labor unions in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.
One of the major labor unions in the transit industry; membership is limited to operators, mechanics and other non-supervisory employees of the transit industry.

An U.S. Bureau of Census-designated area of 50,000 or more inhabitants consisting of a central city or two adjacent cities plus surrounding densely settled territory, but excluding the rural portion of cities.

An U.S. Bureau of Census-designated area of 50,000 or more inhabitants consisting of a central city or two adjacent cities plus surrounding densely settled territory, but excluding the rural portion of cities.

The federal cabinet-level agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation. The DOT includes the Federal Highway Administration and the Federal Transit Administration, among others. There are also state DOTs (WashDOT in Washington)

The federal cabinet-level agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation. The DOT includes the Federal Highway Administration and the Federal Transit Administration, among others. There are also state DOTs (WashDOT in Washington)

The federal cabinet-level agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation. The DOT includes the Federal Highway Administration and the Federal Transit Administration, among others. There are also state DOTs (WashDOT in Washington)

The federal cabinet-level agency with responsibility for highways, mass transit, aviation and ports; headed by the secretary of transportation. The DOT includes the Federal Highway Administration and the Federal Transit Administration, among others. There are also state DOTs (WashDOT in Washington)
An arrangement in which a group of passengers share the use and cost of a van in traveling to and from pre-arranged destinations together.
A cost that varies in relation to the level of operational activity.
This term helps pin down the numbers. Reducing VMT can help ease traffic congestion and improve air quality.

A system of fares where a transit system's service area is divided into zones within which specified rates or fares apply.

A public participation exercise where a diverse group of concerned citizens go online to collectively determine objectives and criteria for transportation improvement in central Puget Sound region of Washington State, analyze the impacts of proposed transportation improvement projects, and recommend their preferred improvement scenario to elected officials.

A person with techsupport role has authority to clarify technical questions about use of data, software, and hardware.  A person with techsupport role has responsibility to suggest fixes for software and hardware.
A person with elected official role has authority to  make a final decision.  A person with elected official role has responsibility to review recommendations and make final decisions.

A person with decision/policy manager role has authority to indicate who can participate.  A person with decision/policy manager role has responsibility to convene a decision process, if this person is employed in the sponsor or has been appointed to do so by the sponsor (authorized) organization, and to clarify the constraints on the process.

A person with transportation information specialist role has authority to address technical questions about transportation improvement, including the data, and the responsibility to clarify technical questions about transportation improvement, including the data

A person with interested/affected individuals role have authority to provide input on anything and everything, articulate/synthesize concerns, evaluate alternatives, and choose recommended alternatives.  A person with interested/affected individuals role have responsibility to contribute as often as desired

termShortDefinition: Detailed fictional participants used in the planning and development process.
termExtendedDefinition: Personas are richly defined fictional participants with personal backgrounds, (mental model differences about interpretation of improvement projects would be most valuable), goals, motivations, values, etc. which are based on user research (interviews, etc.). Backgrounds, goals, motivations, values, can be unpacked into the various parameters.\nOne component of a persona will be the role it plays in a decision process. Designing a system based on roles alone may result in developers making incorrect and/or unstated assumptions about the goals, motivations, values, etc. of the individuals who will play a given role in the decision situation. Introducing personas into the system design process will help to mitigate this problem by providing developers with richly defined individuals with explicitly stated motivations, values, etc. for whom they can design the system. In other words, personas will help us to link the system design to the goals of its users, hopefully resulting in a design that is relevant to the users and a more satisfying user experience.
